title: 104_hr3048
content: The Act may be cited as the "Regulatory Flexibility Amendments Act of 1996". Judicial review is addressed in the Act. Section 611 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow small entities to petition for judicial review of final rules that were certified to have no significant economic impact or had a final regulatory flexibility analysis prepared within one year of the rule's effective date. Small entities can petition for judicial review of final rules certified to have no significant economic impact or with a final regulatory flexibility analysis prepared within one year of the rule's effective date. A court with jurisdiction to review rule compliance can also review the certification or analysis if an agency delays the final regulatory flexibility analysis issuance. A court with jurisdiction to review rule compliance can also review the certification or analysis if an agency delays the final regulatory flexibility analysis issuance. The term 'affected small entity' refers to a small entity adversely affected by the final rule. The deadline for judicial review under this subsection is one year after the analysis is made public. An 'affected small entity' is one negatively impacted by the final rule. This subsection does not limit a court's power to delay a rule's effective date. If an agency certifies no significant economic impact on small entities, the court can order a final preparation. In cases where an agency certifies no significant economic impact on small entities, the court can order the agency to prepare a final regulatory flexibility analysis if the certification is found to be arbitrary or not in accordance with the law. This does not limit the court's power to delay a rule's effective date. The court can order the agency to prepare a final regulatory flexibility analysis if the certification is deemed arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of discretion, or not in accordance with the law. If the agency's final regulatory flexibility analysis was not prepared according to procedure, corrective action can be ordered by the court. The court may order the agency to prepare a final regulatory flexibility analysis if it was not done according to procedure. If the agency fails to comply within 90 days, corrective action can be taken. The court may order the agency to prepare a final regulatory flexibility analysis within 90 days. If the agency fails to comply, corrective action can be taken by the court. The court will consider the rule of prejudicial error in making any determination or granting relief in a judicial review of a rule. The court may stay a rule or grant relief as deemed appropriate, considering prejudicial error. A regulatory flexibility analysis for a rule is part of the record for judicial review. Judicial review of other impact statements required by law is not barred. The regulatory flexibility analysis for a rule is part of the record for judicial review, and judicial review of other impact statements required by law is not barred. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies only to final agency rules issued after the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. Rules commented on by SBA Chief Counsel for Advocacy. Section 612 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include a new subsection requiring agencies to transmit proposed rules and initial regulatory flexibility analysis to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration before publication. Before the 30th day preceding the date of publication of a proposed rule, an agency must send a copy of the rule and the initial regulatory flexibility analysis to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration. The agency must send a proposed rule and initial regulatory flexibility analysis to the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy may provide a written statement on the effect of the proposed rule on small entities within 15 days of receiving the documents. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy can provide a statement on the effect of a proposed rule on small entities within 15 days of receiving the documents. If a statement is provided, the agency must publish it along with their response in the Federal Register. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy can provide a statement on the effect of a proposed rule on small entities. If provided, the agency must publish it along with their response in the Federal Register. Any proposed rules issued by Federal banking agencies, the National Credit Union Administration, or the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight to implement monetary policy or ensure the safety of depository institutions, credit unions, or government housing enterprises shall not be subject to general notice of proposed rulemaking. The implementation of monetary policy or ensuring the safety of depository institutions, credit unions, or government housing enterprises shall not be subject to certain requirements. Section 603(a) of title 5, United States Code, is amended accordingly. Congress believes that the SBA Chief Counsel for Advocacy should have the ability to appear as amicus curiae in court cases reviewing rules.
